infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel
Class TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlain

java.lang.Object
  infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCommon
      infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel.TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlain
All Implemented Interfaces:
ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, TransferEntropyCalculator
public class TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlain
extends TransferEntropyCommon
implements TransferEntropyCalculator

Implements a transfer entropy calculator using kernel estimation. (see Schreiber, PRL 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000)

Usage:

  1. Construct
  2. SetProperty() for each property
  3. intialise()
  4. setObservations(), or [startAddObservations(), addObservations()*, finaliseAddObservations()]. Note: If not using setObservations(), the results from computeLocal or getSignificance are not likely to be particularly sensible.
  5. computeAverageLocalOfObservations() or ComputeLocalOfPreviousObservations()

This implementation is simple, involving O(n^2) comparisons. It incurs a larger memory cost than TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelSimple since it can accomodate multiple time series samples being added. This is a larger memory cost also than TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlainIterators but has a significantly lower cost in time than it.

Author:
Joseph Lizier, joseph.lizier at gmail.com
See Also:
transfer entropy: Schreiber, PRL 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000; http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.461, local transfer entropy: Lizier et al, PRE 77, 026110, 2008; http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.77.026110

computeAverageLocalOfObservationsWithCorrection

public double computeAverageLocalOfObservationsWithCorrection()
                                                       throws java.lang.Exception

Computes the average Transfer Entropy for the previously supplied observations, using the Grassberger correction for the point count k: log_e(k) ~= digamma(k).

Kaiser and Schreiber suggest (on p. 57) that for the TE though the adverse correction of the bias correction is worse than the correction itself (because the probabilities being multiplied/divided are not independent), so recommend not to use this method.

It is implemented here for testing purposes only.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
and Schreiber, Physica D 166 (2002) pp. 43-62

computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
Computes the local transfer entropies for the previous supplied observations. Where more than one time series has been added, the array contains the local values for each tuple in the order in which they were added. If there was only a single time series added, the array contains k zero values before the local values. (This means the length of the return array is the same as the length of the input time series).

Specified by:
computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
Returns:
array of local values.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[] source,
                                                      double[] destination)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
Comptues local transfer entropies for the given observations, using the previously supplied observations to compute the PDFs. I don't think it's such a good idea to do this for continuous variables (e.g. where one can get kernel estimates for probabilities of zero now) but I've implemented it anyway. I guess getting kernel estimates of zero here is no different than what can occur with dynamic correlation exclusion.

Parameters:
source -
destination -
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

computeSignificance

public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon

Compute the significance of obtaining the given average measure from the given observations.

This is as per Chavez et. al., "Statistical assessment of nonlinear causality: application to epileptic EEG signals", Journal of Neuroscience Methods 124 (2003) 113-128.

Basically, we shuffle the source observations against the destination tuples. This keeps the marginal PDFs the same (including the entropy rate of the destination) but destroys any correlation between the source and state change of the destination.

Specified by:
computeSignificance in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
Parameters:
numPermutationsToCheck - number of new orderings of the source values to compare against
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

computeSignificance

public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon

As per computeSignificance() but supplies the re-orderings of the observations of the source variables.

Specified by:
computeSignificance in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
Parameters:
newOrderings - first index is permutation number, i.e. newOrderings[i] is an array of 1 permutation of 0..n-1, where there were n observations. If the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to numObservations, an Exception is thrown.
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
